rules.description: A Counter MUST only be used in combination with a glyph.
A Counter MUST contain exactly one number greater than zero and no other characters.
The Novelty Counter MUST be displayed on the top right of the Glyph it accompanies.
The Novelty Counter SHOULD have an obtrusive background color such as red or orange.
The Status Counter MUST be displayed on the lower right of the item it accompanies.
The Status Counter SHOULD have an non-obtrusive background color such as grey.
A setting MUST be contained by a Titled Form Section.
A setting MUST use an identifier and an input element.
A by-line MUST be placed directly underneath the option it describes.
An identifier MUST be composed of one single term or a very short phrase of no more than 5 words. The identifier is an eye catcher for users skimming the form.
An identifier MUST make a positive statement. If the purpose of the setting is inherently negative, use Verbs as 'Limit..', 'Lock..'.
If by-lines are provided they MUST be informative, not merely repeating the identifier’s or input element’s content. If no informative description can be devised, no description is needed.
By-lines SHOULD be short with no more than 25 words.
A by-line SHOULD NOT address the user directly. Addressing users directly is reserved for cases of high risk of severe mis-configuration.
A by-line MUST be grammatically complete sentence with a period (.) at the end.
Forms MUST NOT be used on the same content screen as tables.
Forms MUST NOT be used on the same content screen as toolbars.
Each form MUST contain at least one titled form section.
In the 'Settings' tab of a module a Titled Form has specific rules: The title of the first Titled Form Section MUST always be 'Edit [NameOfModule]'.
In the 'Settings' tab of a module a Titled Form has specific rules: It’s first Form Settings MUST be 'Title'
In the 'Settings' tab of a module a Titled Form has specific rules: It’s second Form Settings MUST be 'Description'.

The first and last titled form section of a form MUST contain a 'Save' and 'Cancel' button for the form. 'Save' is left and “Cancel” is right. In some rare exceptions the Buttons MAY be named differently: if 'Save' or 'Cancel' are clearly a misleading since the action is more than storing the data into the database. 'Send Mail' would be an example of this.
Proper Titled Form Sections SHOULD comprise 2 to 5 Settings.
More than 5 Settings SHOULD be split into two areas unless this would tamper with the 'familiar' information architecture of forms.
A Titled Form Section MUST contain a title.
The title SHOULD contain less than 30 characters.
Every Input Element in every Input Collection MUST be accessible by keyboard.
All Input Elements visible in a view MUST be accessible by keyboard by using the ‘Tab’-Key.
If focused, the Input Elements MUST change their Input Border Color to the Input Focus Border Color.
A checkbox SHOULD be used whenever a user has to perform a binary choice. You MUST NOT use a Select input or a radio group in this case.
The checkbox’s identifier MUST always state something positive.
If a description is needed, it MUST be placed below the checkbox in the usual place for descriptions of form settings.
If only few items are expected to be selected (<=5), the total number of items to select from SHOULD not be larger than 25. Use a Tag Input otherwise.
Other than for the checkbox input, each checkbox MUST be labeled.
A radio group SHOULD contain 3 to 5 options.
If more than 5 options are available a Select Input SHOULD be used.
Each option in a radio group MUST be labeled.
This label SHOULD not consist of more than 5 words.
If used in forms, the label of the options SHOULD not simply repeat the identifier on the left. A meaningful labeling should be chosen instead.
Select Inputs MUST NOT be used for binary choices.
Select Inputs SHOULD allow user selecting 1 out of N elements where N > 5 and no autocomplete selection is available.
If the number of selectable items is greater than 20 a Tag Input with autocomplete SHOULD be used instead.
Select Inputs MUST NOT for selecting multiple values. Use Tag Input with autocomplete instead.
Buttons MUST NOT be used inside a Textual Paragraph.
The caption of a Button SHOULD contain no more than two words.
Every word except articles, coordinating conjunctions and prepositions MUST be capitalized.
If Text and Glyphs are used alongside as caption for a Button the Glyph MUST be displayed on the left side.
If Text and a Caret are used alongside as caption for a Button the Caret MUST be displayed on the right side.
All glyph-only buttons MUST have aria-labels.
Button DOM elements MUST either be of type “button” or of type “a” accompanied with the aria-role “Button”
The Close Button MUST always be positioned in the top right of a collection.
The functionality of the close button MUST be indicated for screen readers by an aria-label.
There MUST only be one Primary Button per page in ILIAS.
The interaction triggered by the Trigger Element MUST be fired if the ‘Return’-Key is clicked while the element is focused.
All Trigger Elements visible in a view MUST be accessible by keyboard by using the ‘Tab’-Key.
All active Triggers MUST indicate hovering by displaying the cursor as pointer (hand).
All Trigger Elements MUST slightly modify font color, underline or background color on-hovering.
